By Martha Pollard

By Kyle Boulton

Camila HernÃ¡ndez explores the theatrical hues of AlmodÃ³var's 1988 dark comedy

Revival or Just Plain Reboot?

By Martha Pollard

And Just Like That... Carrie Bradshaw, Charlotte, and Miranda are back in the city- leaving a Samantha-shaped hole in our hearts.

The Batman: A Gritty Take on the Caped Crusaderâ€™s Story

By Kyle Boulton

Michael Athey looks at Pattinsonâ€™s performance and the dark aesthetic of the new Batman film

Review: The Northman

By Kyle Boulton

Sophia Ash excavates the bloody core of Robert Eggers' unrelenting blockbuster

Another Year

Mike Leigh's work in film for the past twenty years constitutes a significant oeuvre, and for those who argue that his most recent work is tied a little too strongly to either period drama (<em>Vera Drake</em>, <em>Topsy-Turvy</em>) or a cinema of unvarying mood (<em>All or Nothing</em>, <em>Happy-Go-Lucky</em>), they'll find that <em>Another Year</em> is a rich masterpiece - like <em>Secrets & Lies</em>, it's a great introduction to what Leigh does best

Let Me In

Remakes are risky business in pretty much any context. Occasionally, they end up being better than their source material, a perfect example being Terry Gilliam's borrowing of the themes and style of <em>La Jetee</em> to create <em>Twelve Monkeys</em>, a veritable masterpiece of modern cinema

Burke and Hare

John Landis is perhaps best known for formidable cult classics <em>The Blues Brothers</em>, and <em>An American Werewolf in London</em>, as well as a stream of commercial movies in the seventies and eighties. Burke and Hare, however, is the first film he has directed in twelve years. He seems to have gotten a little rusty...

The Kids Are All Right

I'm not surprised that there's already Oscar buzz surrounding this film. Annette Bening and Julianne Moore create some stunning moments, and both of them might easily be in the running for a couple of gongs come awards season

Saw 3D

Rarely is a sequel better than the original film - but a sixth sequel? Well, let's just say it would have to be superb, and <em>Saw 3D</em> (chronologically, <em>Saw VII</em>) is anything but

Africa United

I promised myself I wouldn't call <em>Africa United</em> - the first feature-length film from director Debs Gardner-Paterson, starring a cast of relative unknowns - the "African <em>Slumdog Millionaire</em>"

Red

In between the releases of heavy literary adaptations <em>The Last Station</em> and <em>The Tempest</em>, Dame Helen Mirren has found herself firing machine guns, sniper rifles and rocket launchers in <em>Red</em>. The value of seeing Queen Elizabeth II put on a menacing expression amidst explosions and shoot-outs manages to be more than just novelty

The Social Network

If asked to describe David Fincher's directorial style, one word that constantly springs to mind is ambitious. Never one to shy away from a challenging storyline, here he tries his hand at dissecting the petty playground politics of Facebook's founders and the subsequent struggle for power in <em>The Social Network</em>

Despicable Me

Let's get this out of the way: I cried at this film. That's not saying much, admittedly, considering you're reading the words of someone who cried at <em>Cool Runnings</em>, but then that same person is one of the few who believes that <em>Cool Runnings</em> is a masterpiece of modern cinema

Come and See (1985)

Critically acclaimed upon its release, and clocking over 25 million admissions in the Soviet Union alone, <em>Come and See</em> is the tale of a child soldier, Florya, and his fight for survival in Nazi occupied Belaru

Temptation and Taqwacores at this year's London Film Festival

Terms at York start late, but not quite late enough to spend a while at the country's biggest film festival, which finishes in a few days time

Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps

Like <em>Platoon</em> that was released the year before it, I like Oliver Stone's <em>Wall Street </em>not just for its political and social relevance, but because of its enjoyable simplicity

Mr Nice

Howard Marks must be rubbing his hands with glee; not many criminals manage to have so much control over their own legacy, at least not without seeming repugnant in some way (last year's biopic of Charles Bronson comes to mind)

After I'm Still Here, where can satires of Hollywood go next?

In 2008, with a grizzly beard and a noticeably growing belly, actor Joaquin Phoenix announced that he'd be retiring from acting to pursue a career in hip-hop. His brother-in-law, fellow actor Casey Affleck, would document the career move and Phoenix's life at home

Made in Dagenham

40 years on from the passing of the Equal Pay Act, a film has been made that continues the Act's tradition not of feminism, but of egalitarianism

The Secret of Kells

<em>The Secret of Kells</em> is an entirely untypical specimen of a children's film

All the President's Men (1976)

A 1976 film based on the 1974 non-fiction book of the same name by Bob Woodward and Carl Bernstein (who are here played by Robert Redford and a simply brilliant Dustin Hoffman), <em>All the President's Men</em> is a personal account of two journalists investigating the infamous Watergate scandal for <em>The Washington Post</em>

Buried

There's only so much a film set entirely in a coffin can do, but <em>Buried</em> succeeds in just about doing it all

Eat Pray Love

As a reviewer, I feel obliged to point out that this film is... only alright. So-so. Watchable

The Town

<em>The Town</em> was bound to do well. Boasting a series of star names, a bombastic trailer and a big budget, this could have had no substance whatsoever and it would still rake in unjustified millions. What a relief, then, that it's a great film

The Other Guys

A cop movie whose cast boasts Mark Wahlberg, Michael Keaton, and Eva Mendes doesn't sound like the latest Will Ferrell/Adam McKay film; but maybe if you'd been in serious police dramas like The Corruptor, Desperate Measures and Training Day, then you'd be happy to jump onboard with the duo behind Anchorman and Talladega Nights to show audiences that you still had a sense of humour

The Runaways

Going into the cinema to see <em>The Runaways</em>, I couldn't help but feel ambivalent. On the one hand, it's a kinda-sorta-but-not-really biopic of Cherie Currie and Joan Jett, the two lead members of the titular band, and there's some defiantly feminist streak in me that means I get a kick out of seeing girls rocking out and telling the rest of the world where to stick it

Cyrus

The Duplass Brothers offer up a charming film that might easily have turned out a full-on gag-fest. Whilst it will consistently tickle you, the humour isn't belly-ache funny... but this is a good thing

Dinner for Schmucks

Remakes have a difficult time in the modern world of film, since they usually try and re-imagine a concept which is jealously guarded by the viewer, and they require walking a very fine tightrope to satisfy both the purists and the newcomers

22 Bullets

The main character of <em>22 Bullets</em> clearly never saw <em>The Godfather</em>, or at least he stopped watching it before the attempted assassination of Vito Corleone

Mother

Whilst South Korea's most internationally famous filmmaker in recent years has been <em>Oldboy</em> and <em>Lady Vengeance</em> revenge maestro Chan-wook Park, his contemporary Bong Joon-ho is starting to merit equal attention, as a director whose films also have their own set of recurring themes told with an idiosyncratic visual and dramatic style

Knight and Day

So, I confess, I am a Tom Cruise addict, and despite the wealth of criticism he receives, and despite his fall from box office grace, I still eagerly anticipate his films. So for me, <em>Knight and Day</em> was no exception, and it was an enjoyable, light-hearted popcorn film

Salt

Amongst the many effects of George W. Bush's presidency, a probably unimportant consequence has been overlooked: for much of the past decade, thrillers have been unable to include an American President as a character without implying to the audience that he's either greedy, over-powerful, stupid or evil

The Expendables

An interesting Belgian film called JCVD was released a couple of years ago. It's about an ageing action star - played by the actor himself - who is unwittingly caught up in a bank robbery, before being accused by police of being one of its perpetrators

The Secret in their Eyes

The winner of this year's Oscar for Best Foreign Language Film, The Secret in their Eyes feels very much like a classic genre film

Another Year
